article.title: Analytic model of a multi-electron atom

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the x-axis of Figure 1 represent?
choices: The number of electrons in the atom
The principal quantum number of the atom\'s ground state
The nucleus\' charge Z (equal to the number of electrons)
The effective nuclear charge Z*

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend does Figure 1 illustrate about the relative error of the calculated total atomic energy?
choices: The relative error increases with increasing nuclear charge for both zeroth-order and corrected energies.
The relative error remains relatively constant with increasing nuclear charge for both zeroth-order and corrected energies.
The relative error decreases with increasing nuclear charge for both zeroth-order and corrected energies.
The single-electron excitation correction has a negligible impact on the relative error compared to the zeroth-order approximation.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main difference between the blue solid line and the red dashed-dotted line in Figure 2?
choices: The red dashed-dotted line includes the single-electron excitation first-order correction, while the blue solid line does not.
The blue solid line represents a relativistic calculation, while the red dashed-dotted line represents a non-relativistic calculation.
The red dashed-dotted line represents the analytical zeroth-order approximation, while the blue solid line represents a numerical solution.
The blue solid line accounts for electron correlation, while the red dashed-dotted line does not.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which approximation in Figure 2 shows the least agreement with the Hartree-Fock calculation for both Ne and Ar?
choices: Analytical zeroth-order approximation (green dashed line)
Single-electron excitation corrected (red dashed-dotted line)
Thomas-Fermi model (purple dotted line)
All approximations show comparable agreement with the Hartree-Fock calculation.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the graphs in Figure 3 depict?
choices: The radial electron density as a function of distance from the nucleus
The energy levels of the atoms as a function of nuclear charge
The atomic scattering factors as a function of the parameter s
The relative error of the calculated energies compared to experimental values

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded from Figure 3 regarding the accuracy of the analytical zeroth-order approximation for atomic scattering factors?
choices: The approximation shows good agreement with the Gaussian fit of relativistic HF calculations for lighter elements, but the discrepancy increases for heavier elements.
The approximation provides accurate results for all elements regardless of their atomic number.
The approximation consistently underestimates the atomic scattering factors compared to the Gaussian fit of relativistic HF calculations.
The approximation is only valid for elements with spherically symmetric electron densities.

multiple_choice_question.text: Formula (5) defines the effective charge Z*. What does the term B/2A in this formula represent?
choices: The total energy of the atom
The screening effect of the other electrons
The kinetic energy of the electron under consideration
The exchange interaction energy

multiple_choice_question.text: Formula (19) represents the calculated total energy of the system in second-order perturbation theory. What is the physical meaning of the term Î”E^(2)_multi?
choices: The energy correction due to the interaction of an electron with its own electric field.
The energy correction due to the interaction of an electron with the average field of all other electrons.
The energy correction due to the instantaneous pairwise interaction between electrons.
The energy correction due to relativistic effects.
